Body: 和製英語wasei eigo is an occurrence of Japanese that's made up of English words. For example "サラリーマンsalaryman" is composed of the words "salary" and "man", but the word itself isn't an English word, except as a loanword from Japanese when describing the work culture in Japan.

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
I'm a Cantonese native speaker from Guangzhou,China. My major is Event Management, branching from Tourism.I love traveling around and also have a burning passion for languages and that I felt really excited when bumping into this site.

Languages List ## With reference to Alenanno's

                 Languages with * = learning on my own

Mother Tongue: 廣東話Cantonese, （漢語/汉语)Mandarin Chinese ;

Fluent: English, 日本語*;

Less Fluent: Español*,한국어*,français;

Learning:Italiano*,Português*,Русский*

Willing to learn: Swedish, Deutsch[to be continued]

OwnerUser.AboutMe:
I work at the University of New South Wales, where I use Ruby to analyze biological data.

In part of my spare time, I work on fun programming projects. One was trying to analyze what underlies Wikipedia's Get to Philosophy game. I also worked on one called the "Small Eigen Collider".

I'm currently learning Japanese, and I'm an active participant in lang-8.com, a website where you write journal entries in a language you're learning, and get corrected by native speakers of that language. In return, you correct people writing entries in your native language. Recently, I've been asking a few questions prompted by slightly incorrect English I've encountered on lang-8.
